questions.question: A 3-year-old child with the following finding has high myopia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The image shows corectopia, an abnormal eccentrically placed pupil.It can be a congenital anomaly or an acquired defect with essential iris atrophy. It may beassociated with high myopia or ectopia lentis, among other conditions.

questions.question: 333A patient presents to the casualty after ocular trauma with a D-shaped pupil. What is thelikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A D-shaped pupil is seen in iridodialysis.Iridodialysis is the dis-insertion of the iris root from the ciliary body attachment. It may occurfollowing ocular trauma. A red reflex can be obtained from the peripheral gap in the iris.The given image depicts iridodialysis and a D-shaped pupil.340IridodialysisD shaped pupilDAILYROUNDS

questions.question: Which of the following is the pathognomonic sign of acute anterior uveitis?
questions.explanation: The pathognomonic sign of acute anterior uveitis is keratic precipitates (KP).Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular deposits at the back of cornea. The composition ofKPs varies with the type of uveitis.Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris to the pars plicata of theciliary body. Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis:• Corneal signs• Corneal edema• Keratic precipitates (Pathognomonic)•⚫ Posterior corneal opacity.Anterior chamber signs•Aqueous cells..• Aqueous flare (earliest sign)• Hypopyon• Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae• Iris signs••• Loss of normal patternChange in color• Iris nodules (Koeppe, Busacca)⚫ Posterior synechiae•• Neovascularization341• Pupillary signs• Constricted pupil•• Irregular pupil shapeEctropion of pupillary margin•Occlusion pupillaeSigns of anterior uveitisKeratic precipitatesOMARROWCircumcornealcongestion-Segmentalposteriorsynechia-Festooned pupil

questions.question: What is the first sign a patient with anterior uveitis may show?
questions.explanation: Aqueous flare is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis.Aqueous flare is due to the leakage of protein particles into the aqueous humor from damagedblood vessels. It is demonstrated on the slit-lamp examination. It is based on the principleof Brownian movement or Tyndall phenomenon.Aqueous flare is usually marked in non-granulomatous uveitis and minimal in granulomatousuveitis. The presence of cells in the anterior chamber denotes an active inflammatory process.The image below is a high magnification slit-beam photograph 3×1 mm in size in a darkroomshowing the presence of cells and flare.342

questions.question: A 34-year-old lady presents with eye pain, photophobia, and red-eye. The slit-lampexamination finding is shown below. On which layer of the cornea are these present?334
questions.explanation: Eye pain, photophobia and red-eye along with the slit lamp finding of keratic precipitates suggestsa diagnosis of acute anterior uveitis. Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellulardeposits occurring at the back of the corneal endothelium.Keratuc precipitates are arranged in a triangular fashion, occupying the center and inferiorparts of the cornea (Arlt's triangle).

questions.question: You are evaluating a 45-year-old man admitted for acute anterior uveitis. What is thepupillary shape you expect to find in his eyes?
questions.explanation: The pupil in acute anterior uveitis is constricted (pupillary sphincter spasm), irregular andsluggishly reactive to lightIn an acute attack of uveitis, the pupil is irregular and narrow due to irritation of sphinchterpupillae. Pupillary signs in chronic anterior uveitis is as follows:• Festooned pupil results from the application of mydriatics in segmental posterior synechiae.•Occlusio pupillae results when the pupil is completely occluded due to the organization of theexudates across the pupillary area.•Seclusio pupillae due to ring synechiae, that prevent the circulation of aqueous humor from theposterior chamber to the anterior chamber.The image below shows a festooned pupil.343

questions.question: A patient with sarcoidosis shows Koeppe's nodules on ophthalmologic examination. Whereare these seen?
questions.explanation: Koeppe's nodules and Bussaca's nodules develop on the iris in granulomatous uveitis.Granulomatous uveitis is a chronic proliferative inflammation seen in reponse to tuberculosis,leprosy, syphilis and sarcoidosis. Infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, with proliferationof mononuclear cells leads to the formation of iris nodule. Koeppe's nodules are seen atthe pupillary margin. Bussaca's nodules are seen on the peripheral part of the anterior surface ofiris.Busacca's noduleKoeppe's nodules

questions.question: What is the type of synechiae formed in iris bombe?
questions.explanation: DAILYROUNDS344Iris bombe formation is due to the development of annular or ring synechiae.Annular posterior/ring synechiae are 360° adhesions of the pupillary margin to the anteriorcapsule of the lens. They prevent the circulation of aqueous humor from the posterior chamber tothe anterior chamber (seclusio pupillae). Thus, the aqueous collects behind the iris and pushes itanteriorly leading to iris bombe. This is usually followed by a rise in intraocular pressure. Theanterior chamber is funnel-shaped when ring synechiae are present.The image below shows iris bombe on slit lamp examination.MAnnular or Ring synechiaeOMARROWIris Bombe

questions.question: A 38-year-old woman has been having repeated episodes of red-eye, eye pain, and blurredvision. She is diagnosed with chronic granulomatous uveitis. Which of the following is not acause?
questions.explanation: Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a type of non-granulomatous uveitis.345Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is an insidious progressive anterior uveitis. It is mostlyunilateral and associated with early cataract formation. Stellate keratic precipitates are seen andthere is a notable absence of posterior synechiae.Causes for chronic granulomatous uveitis include sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, herpes simplex,herpes zoster, syphilis, leprosy, brucellosis and phacoanaphylactic.

questions.question: Intermediate uveitis is also called as
questions.explanation: Intermediate uveitis refers to pars planitis. It involves inflammation of the pars plana.The uvea consists of the iris, ciliary body and choroid. Inflammation of uveal tissue is calleduveitis. It can be classified anatomically as follows:• Anterior uveitis: Inflammation of iris and pars plicata, consisting of iritis, iridocyclitis andanterior cyclitis• Intermediate uveitis: Inflammation of pars plana (pars planitis)• Posterior uveitis: Inflammation of the retina with or without involvement of the retina. Itincludes choroiditis, chorioretinitis, retinochoroiditis and neuroretinitis.• PanuveitisPathological classification divides uveitis into suppurative and nonsuppurative uveitis.Nonsuppurative uveitis is further classified into nongranulomatous and granulomatous uveitis.The image is a schematic representation of the anatomical classification of uveitis.Anatomical classification of uveitisAnteriorIntermediatePosteriorOMARROW

questions.question: In a patient with intermediate uveitis, which of the following is a pathognomonic examinationfinding?
questions.explanation: Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis.W346Snow banking refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or withoutperipheral retinal periphlebitis.Intermediate uveitis is the inflammation of the pars plana and presents with retrolental flare, fewkeratic precipitates, vitreous cells and snow-ball opacities (Ant's egg opacities). These are typicalexudates present near the ora serrata in the inferior quadrant.Treatment of intermediate uveitis is by the Kaplan 4-step protocol:• Periocular steroid: Sub tenon injection of triamcinolone acetate•Systemic steroid•Cryotherapy over snow banking• Pars plana vitrectomyIntermediate uveitisSnowball opacities andvitreous veils in pars planitisInferior snow banking withvitreous exudatesOMARROW

questions.question: While studying a cohort of patients with juvenile idiopathic arthritis, you are evaluating therisk of iridocyclitis among the different subtypes of JIA. Which subtype has the highest risk ofiridocyclitis associated?
questions.explanation: ANA-positive oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is associated with the highest riskfor iridocyclitis (uveitis).A positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test result confers increased risk for uveitis in children withJIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination. Uveitis in JIA is characteristically chronic,non-granulomatous, and bilateral. It presents as a white eye without congestion- white uveitis.Complications include complicated cataracts, secondary glaucoma, and band-shaped keratopathy.Note: Intraocular lens (IOL) implantation can be considered in most pediatric patients withwell-controlled uveitis, but JIA-associated uveitis should be considered as a relativecontraindication.

questions.question: Where is Amsler's sign seen?
questions.explanation: 347Amsler sign is seen in Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI).Amsler sign is the hemorrhage caused by cataract surgery in FHI. During cataract surgery, finefiliform hemorrhages from the opposite angle are seen to occur as soon as the anterior chamber isopened. This is due to neovascularization.beFuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is an insidiously progressive, non- granulomatous anterioruveitis, that is usually unilateral. Stellate KPs are seen and tiny crystals (Russell bodies) maypresent on the iris surface. There are no posterior synechiae. Rubeosis iridis may be present.The 1st image shows Fuchs heterochromic uveitis. The right eye is normal. The left hypochromiceye is affected. The 2nd image shows stellate keratic precipiates.

questions.question: What is Posner-Schlossman syndrome?

options.A: Ipsilateral optic atrophy with contralateral papilloedemac
options.B: Unilateral glaucomatous changes with mild anterior uveitis

questions.explanation: (b)348Posner-Schlossman syndrome is characterized by unilateral glaucomatous changes with mildanterior uveitis.This syndrome, also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis or hypertensive uveitis, presentswith recurrent unilateral attachs of acute raised intraocular pressure (IOP) (>40 mmHg)changes, fine white central keratic precipitates (KPS) and mydriasis. Treatment includes topicalcorticosteroids, cycloplegics, and aqueous suppressants.

questions.question: A 44-year-old patient with AIDS and opportunistic infections was started on treatment. Hedevelops a sterile hypopyon anterior uveitis that is suspected to be drug-induced. Which ofthe following drugs may be implicated here?
questions.explanation: Rifabutin causes uveitis in AIDS patients.Causes of drug-induced uveitis include:• Cidofovir• Rifabutin• Bisphosphonates• Oral moxifloxacin

questions.question: Which among the following is associated with transient hypopyon syndrome?
questions.explanation: Behcet's disease presents with recurrent iridocyclitis associated with transient hypopyon.Behcet's disease is a systemic vascular disease. It is associated with HLA B5 >> B51. Patientshave obliterative vasculitis due to circulating immune complexes, leading to a recurrent, bilateralnon-granulomatous uveitis. There is acute recurrent iridocyclitis, transient hypopyon,periphlebitis, retinitis, vitritis and cystoid macular edema (CME).

questions.question: A patient presents with photophobia and blurring of vision. On examination, the eye appearsas shown below. What is the mainstay of treatment?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario of photophobia and blurring of vision along with red-eye and irregularlyshaped pupil suggests a diagnosis of anterior uveitis. Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay ofthe treatment of uveitis.Steroids are the drug of choice in anterior uveitis. They reduce inflammation by theiranti-inflammatory effect. Cycloplegics like 1% atropine relieve spasm of the iris sphincter andciliary muscles. They prevent the formation of synechiae and reduce exudation. Systemictherapy includes steroids, NSAIDs, and immunosuppressants.Immunosuppressants like voclosporin (calcineurin inhibitor) are used in severe cases. They arebeing studied under a program called LUMINATE.349
